prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: PG1011-040 CO(2-1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This SB consists of a pointed observation of PG1011-040 in the light of CO(2-1).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: PG 1011-040 has a CO(1-0) flux of S_co*Delta v ~ 5.85 Jy km / s and an estimated CO(2-1) flux of 10.5 Jy km/s. The host has a line width of 160 km/s, which corresponds to a peak flux density of 66 Jy for CO(2-1). If we adopt the conservative estimate that the CO(2-1) emission is extended over an area equivalent to a diameter of 0.6", the rms per channel is 0.91 mJy, and it will take 31 minutes, including calibrations, to achieve a S/N ~ 8 per velocity resolution channel (50 km/s). This is a conservation estimate - the CO emission is likely to be clumpy.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: PG 1119+120 has a CO(1-0) flux of S_co*Delta v ~ 2.67 Jy km / s and an estimated CO(2-1) flux of 4.8 Jy km/s. The host has a line width of 217 km/s, which corresponds to a peak flux density of 22 Jy for CO(2-1). This is a conservation estimate - the CO emission is likely to be clumpy.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose CO(2-1) observations of a sample of 6 Palomar-Green (PG) QSO hosts known to be rich in molecular gas. This sample provides the best opportunity to measure the distribution, gas surface density and kinematics in the hosts of luminous QSOs. ALMA observations of CO(2-1) emission are ideal for tracing the bulk of the molecular gas at resolutions (0.2"= 0.2 kpc for z = 0.05) which can be used to assess both nuclear and extended gas. Our proposed observations will allow us to (a) measure the spatial distribution of molecular gas relative to stellar light and the radio/1mm emission, (b) determine whether QSO hosts follow the same star formation law as their putative evolutionary precursors - the ULIRG population, (c) measure the range of IR surface densities for comparison with models of star formation regulation through radiation pressure on dust, and (d) assess whether the molecular gas is in a disk and if there is evidence of outflows. By making use of ALMA and the present sample of gas-rich QSO hosts, this survey will result in a study the ISM and star formation in extreme AGN systems via diagnostics typically reserved for nearby normal galaxies and local ULIRGs.
